title: Suffering in Imagination
author: Seneca
content: We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.

title: Death as Natural
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: Death smiles at us all, but all a man can do is smile back.

title: Power Over Mind
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: You have power over your mind—not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.

title: Obstacles as the Way
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.

title: Fortune's Gifts
author: Seneca
content: Every new thing excites the mind, but a thing which is familiar becomes a burden.

title: Present Moment
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: Confine yourself to the present—the present time, the present action, the present thought.

title: Life's Brevity
author: Seneca
content: Life is long if you know how to use it. It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.

title: Virtue as Sole Good
author: Epictetus
content: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants. The greatest remedy for anger is delay.

title: Morning Reflection
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: When you wake up in the morning, tell yourself: the people I deal with today will be meddling, ungrateful, arrogant, dishonest, jealous and surly.

title: Philosophy as Medicine
author: Seneca
content: Philosophy does not promise to secure anything external for man, otherwise it would be admitting something that lies beyond its proper subject-matter.

title: Dichotomy of Control
author: Epictetus
content: Some things are within our power, while others are not. Within our power are opinion, motivation, desire, aversion, and, in a word, whatever is of our own doing.

title: Universal Connection
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: We were born to work together like feet, hands, and eyes, like the two rows of teeth, upper and lower. To obstruct each other is unnatural.

title: Time's True Value
author: Seneca
content: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it. Life is long enough if you know how to use it.

title: Anger's Futility
author: Seneca
content: How much trouble he avoids who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does, but only to what he does himself, that it may be just and pure.

title: Character Formation
author: Epictetus
content: Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it. Every art and every inquiry, and similarly every action and pursuit, is thought to aim at some good; and for this reason the good has rightly been declared.

title: The Discipline of Desire
author: Epictetus
content: When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive—to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love—then make that day count. Don't postpone joy until you have learned all of your lessons. Joy is your lesson.

title: Cosmic Perspective
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: Remember that very little disturbs the balance of nature. A small stone can alter the course of a great avalanche, but consider: the avalanche was already unstable. Most of what we call 'problems' are simply the universe seeking equilibrium through us.

title: Wealth and Poverty
author: Seneca
content: It is equally faulty to trust everyone and to trust no one. The person who is not aware that he has enough is poor indeed, regardless of his possessions. Set aside a certain number of days during which you shall be content with the scantiest and cheapest fare, with coarse and rough dress, saying to yourself the while.

title: The View from Above
author: Marcus Aurelius
content: You can rid yourself of many useless things among those that disturb you, for they lie entirely in your imagination. You will then gain for yourself much time and peace by comprehending the whole universe in your mind and observing the rapidity of change in each created thing, and seeing how brief is the time from birth to dissolution, and how vast the time before birth, and equally vast the time that follows dissolution.

title: The Philosophical Life
author: Seneca
content: Philosophy is not a trick that has been devised for the display of words, but a way of life. It is not concerned with pleasing the ear, but with helping the soul. It is not pursued in order that the day may yield some amusement before it is spent, or that our leisure may be relieved of a tedium that irks us. It shapes and constructs the soul; it orders our life, guides our conduct, shows us what we should do and what we should leave undone; it sits at the helm and directs our course as we waver amid uncertainties. Without it, no one can live fearlessly or in peace of mind.
